It's just so touching when Mr. Bruni's quarterly teacher bashing column comes out. Something just has to be done about those teachers but that's because of his deep love for our children.

America is the only country that I am aware of that lays the blame for its educational malaise and failures at the feet of its teachers. But if the quality of public school teachers is so abysmal, is that also true of private or parochial schools? Are we to believe that public schools get the bottom of the barrel in teaching quality and private and parochial schools get the cream of the crop? The great majority of teachers, in private, parochial or public schools all go to the same schools of education.

Finland has no schools of education. Teachers can only come from ten or so selected universities, must get a master's degree in an academic subject, even elementary school teachers, and they must be in the top ten percent of their class.

Sit back and watch that battle if the US ever tried to take away the cash cows of schools of education from higher education. American institutions such as the media, politicians and much of the public want better public schools but only if they can keep laying the blame for educational failure at the feet of teachers. If they have to go beyond teacher bashing, well, the enthusiasm for reform begins to quickly wane, especially if the solutions are expensive.

Well, half of what you say is true. What isn't true is that the teachers today are of the quality of the teachers you and I had when we were young. They aren't. My mom, who did teacher evaluations for the NYC public schools and was herself a product of the public school system, was appalled by what she saw. She gave an example of a teacher who led her class in a song about a doggie over and over again. When she asked the teacher afterwards why she hadn't done, that the teacher explained that she'd finished her lesson plan early. She compared them to cocktail waitresses. As Mr. Bruni says, these teachers have average SAT scores of 900. Where I think you're right is that to get better teachers, we have to improve the problems you mentioned, e.g., disruptive kids with no recourse, no support from administrators. I know talented teachers who left the profession and won't go back because of this crap. And we have to address salary equality, and certification requirements that favor unqualified ed school graduates over teachers with specialized skills in math, science, literature, language, and other areas. You don't need ed school to teach high school, you need a knowledge of one's topic.

There is a tight U.S. House race here in Hawaii, the President's birthplace (even if that fact may be disputed by some fringe Republicans.) We only have two House seats, same as number of U.S. senators, so people here to seem the think of the two offices almost interchangeably. House result here of course won't change the balance in that chamber, but the Republican (Asian-American, military veteran) is characterizing himself as moderate and willing to work across the aisle, while the Democrat is promoting himself as some sort of legacy candidate (i.e. also Asian-American veteran but with deeper ties to the  community by means of long state government service.) It will be very tight, but the President's home state, and former home district, may well send a Republican to the House.

I was a sorority member at a four-year state university, and the membership and residence fees were all made clear in the summer in a mailing prior to rush. They were very moderate; quite similar to housing in student apartments and dorms. For me, sorority life was a very positive experience. There were no fines for missing activities, and my house had both the highest average GPA and the largest number of varsity athletes of any house on campus for many of the quarters I was in residence. Several of our members were involved in student government, served as reporters for the campus newspaper, held other jobs and were active in all kinds of committees. We would never, ever have been dissuaded from studying or penalized for doing so. That would make no sense - houses that fall below a certain GPA lose their national charter.

Our membership was diverse, and we all had outside friends and interests as well as close friendships within the house. Our house was not unusual in this regard.

It's easy to feed into traditional stereotypes, and this article is full of them. I'm not arguing that there is no truth in these individual examples, there may be. I am arguing that this article does not have much balance, because there is no representation of anyone with a different point of view. And as someone who has stayed in touch with my sorority sisters - with daughters who are now in school, I'm quite certain that another, more positive experience still exists.
My daughter joined Alpha Phi last year. At least for her, it has been one of her best college experiences. I pay the financial cost and am glad to do so.
"You gotta fight, for your right, to paarrrttteeee"!
Read "Eating the Cheshire Cat" by Helen Ellis. It's fiction, but it doesn't exaggerate in its outrageous, dark storytelling of Southern sorority life and culture.
Sororities don't train women to be like that, their mothers do.  I have encountered plenty of women like you describe who never went to college, never mind being in a sorority.

"I would go further in suggesting advanced degrees (MS or ME) in the sciences rather than masters in education degrees."

I'm not sure I agree with you that doing advanced research in a narrow academic topic will improve someone's ability to teach general subject matter to children. I'm not saying there isn't value in improving the content competency of teaching candidates--there certainly is. But all of us who've gone to a major university and been taught by a celebrated academic (especially in the sciences) can attest to the fact that research success does not correlate to good teaching.

A wonderful piece. There is an argument to be made that teaching should be held in the same esteem as medicine or engineering. The difference, as rightly pointed out in this article (amazing to see it in the liberal Times), is selection criteria in education school. Is it any wonder that own schools are failing when becoming a teacher is a fallback major? Make it hard,  give it stature, and demand more from our educators. I also commend the idea of different pay for different fields of teaching. I would go further in suggesting advanced degrees (MS or ME) in the sciences rather than masters in education degrees. The notion of 'Those that can't do... " should be over.

Actually, Mr. Bruni is right. Studies find that teacher quality makes all the difference. And no, the teachers we are getting today are not of the same quality as the teachers we used to get, because women used to be forced into teaching by employment discrimination, and because conditions are now dreadful and pay and respect are low. You have no idea how bad the current crop of teachers is (not all, of course -- were' talking average). Or how difficult it is to fire even the incompetent ones.
This just isn't true. The figures support Mr. Bruni's point -- low SAT scores, low class rank. There are still fine teachers, of course, but the overall quality of candidates has plummeted.

Hi, Discussant. I was waiting to see how long it would take to see your negative posts on therapy. I'm sure you're aware that many therapies, including CBT, work on supporting positive and practical coping skills. Many therapies are short-term; many are based on solidly research.

You question a therapist saying, for example, "The first time he went on vacation, he asked me how I felt about being left by him" and interpret that as narcissitic, pathological, a "red flag"; it can also be interpreted as a therapist who is sensitive to feelings that some clients do actually have during absences in therapy. Who's to say what is the "correct" interpretation here?

You say "similar pathological characteristics typical of therapists" is also an assumption that it is typical that therapists are pathological. While I understand that you may be "anti-therapy" I don't think its true that all therapy is bad therapy.

You make sense to be sure that consumers are aware of possible bad effects of (some) therapies. I do wish you would also acknowledge that many consumers have as well found they received good experiences in therapy. Fortunately, other posters have done so. I would also add that while you often site website links for readers, many of these are unmoderated anti-therapy sites, usually based on anecdotes, such as "psychgripe" and "ironshrink." I would be more comfortable with more "scientific" sites that use strong research techniques and evidence-based outcomes. Thank you.

Mr. Bruni, the constant drumbeat of "bad" teachers and the never-ending disrespect for those of us who serve in the profession is not a recipe to turn things around. You will only get worse teachers and more failing schools. Who among us wants to serve in jobs with low pay with even lower prestige. It is the rare person who doesn't go into a career for one or the other, unless you are expecting all teachers to be saints, which I'm afraid is a leftover from the days when women were literally "called" to become teachers because they were deemed motherly and could be paid less than men.

Having begun my career when women had few choices, and having left to work in the corporate world, I can tell you that the job of a teacher is far more difficult than any other I've experienced. Our biggest challenge is to support teachers, especially in the first few years, so that they don't quit --- about 50% do. That must tell you there's something wrong.

Tenure is needed so that teachers can advocate for their students without fear of retribution. Yes, teaching is more political than many might believe. Administrators often have conflicting agendas and little experience teaching. Many teachers are removed without firing by counseling someone out of the profession, but most likely people select themselves out after they see how much the job demands and see that they're not up to it.

Common Core and even large class sizes are generally not difficulties or obstacles in middle-class suburban schools. These are really only issues in schools than contain a high number of ill-prepared, unmotived, surly, disruptive or otherwise problematic students as frequently typifies our inner city middle and high schools; we cannot have an honest conversation about education if we do not acknowledge this fact.

I will simply echo those who disagree with this. Common Core - "teaching to the test" - is the single biggest mistake this country has ever made in its educational system. Even class size, school choice, and other factors pale in comparison. Teachers cannot BE "great" teachers if they are so limited in what - and even how - they can teach. Period.

Get ride of "teaching to the test," cut down classroom sizes (in those schools that have this issue), pay teachers better (as at least one commenter notes, "economics" is the elephant in the room), and you will see just how quickly things start turning around.

Sarah, I think you're missing the point. It isn't just about the value of the subject, but about supply and demand. Schools can't find qualified math teachers at the salaries they pay, but they can find plenty of qualified coaches. It's a lot easier to become a coach than it is to get a degree in mathematics, and mathematicians have plenty of employment opportunities that pay more than teaching does. If you want qualified math and science teachers, you're going to have to pay them more.

Government run compulsory education is probably the most successful social program in history. You will find it in every rich country and you will find that a lack of universal education characterizes the poorest ones. You seem to be confusing the problems of certain groups, disproportionately poor, Hispanic, and black, with overall educational outcomes. And even the kids who do poorly at school are better off knowing what they do.

Fair points. But while you are correct that it is difficult to "rescue" a 16 or 17 year old child, I hope you would agree that these issues likely didn't appear overnight. That same child was once 12 years old in junior high school or 8 years old in elementary school. Shouldn't the teachers of these children help them understand how to learn and prepare for the older years ?

And I would agree that behavioral issues make learning more difficult. And teachers should be supported not only by tax payers, but also by their administrators to try to demonstrate a way forward for these students. As you point out. But if teachers don't help these students and their parents are not supportive, then what future do these students have ? And given that failure in school often leads to poverty, how can the nation itself heal ?

The difficult part is this: there's no shortage of qualified teachers in the 'burbs; its the cities, and particularly the inner city, where the notion of "qualified teacher" becomes much more difficult.

And to be blunt: few people, particularly academic masters of their respective subjects, are prepared to take on the chaos and occasional violence of a classroom of young adults who populate the typical failing urban school.

To phrase it another way: it is insane to expect teachers to "rescue a child from a lifetime of struggle" when that "child" is 16 or 17 yo, is perhaps a parent themselves, has completely checked out of the educational process and resents those who try to succeed.

Would we get to the point where the quality of academics were a driving concern; instead, its the controlling of basic behavioral issues of the students that drive many of these problem classrooms, and result in the high burnout and almost impossible ability to retain competent instructors.

Which made me wonder: when Mr. Bruni referred to "poor parents", was it their cash flow, or their abject failure in rearing their children to respect education that he was referencing?

"that the kind of person we want as a teacher can make much more money and earn much more respect as a physician, lawyer, engineer, professor, or executive."

I believe that this was mentioned in the article. Teachers should be paid more, but we cannot afford to simply do this w/o also raising average teacher quality. There are already stars, but that's not enough. As our HS Principal once said (more or less; this was a few years ago), we want all our teachers to be stars.

Higher pay is a necessary part of this, but so are the needed changes in how teachers are themselves educated (both initially and ongoing) and selected.

I also believe that there should be more of a science to assigning students to teachers. My eldest has a fantastic teacher that touched his life in a way he'll always remember, but she and my youngest were a weirdly volatile mix that did not work. Both did very well with others, so this wasn't an issue with either the teacher or my youngest; some pairings simply don't succeed.

I like to cite this to show that it's not always as simple as good or bad teachers or students.

One important difference might be the degree of calm the treatment teams have when they are treating only a single patient.  They can use all necessary caution, watch each other dress, decontaminate, and degarb without the mental demands of having ten other direly ill patients on the same ward.  They are also unlikely to run into Ebola anywhere else but in that single room.  They are probably better rested, too.

If workers who had contact with Ebola patients in Africa are quarantined, shouldn't health care workers who treat Ebola patients in the US also be quarantined (as was shown in Dallas, they too can catch the disease). Then who would be left to treat new patients?
